question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Bonnie B. McConnell's employer in 2048?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Title: The Rhythms of Health: Bonnie B. McConnell's Journey at Australian National University

In the heart of Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, the Australian National University (ANU) stood as a beacon of academic excellence, attracting scholars from around the world. Among them was Bonnie B. McConnell, a renowned ethnomusicologist and health educator, whose groundbreaking work would leave an indelible mark on the institution. Bonnie's fascination with the intersection of music, culture, and health began early in her career. As an ethnomusicologist, she delved into the world of traditional music, exploring its role in shaping community identities and promoting well-being. Her research took her to remote corners of the globe, from the vibrant streets of Brazil to the rural villages of Africa. Wherever she went, Bonnie's passion for music and its therapeutic potential only grew stronger. It was this passion that led Bonnie to the Australian National University, where she joined the faculty as a researcher and lecturer. Her appointment marked the beginning of a new chapter in her career, one that would see her collaborate with scholars from diverse disciplines to advance our understanding of music's impact on human health. One of Bonnie's earliest projects at ANU focused on the role of traditional music in Indigenous Australian communities. Working closely with local elders and musicians, she documented the ways in which music was used to promote physical and mental well-being, particularly in the face of colonial trauma. Her research revealed the profound significance of music in preserving cultural heritage and fostering community resilience. Bonnie's work soon gained international recognition, attracting the attention of health professionals and policymakers. Her expertise was sought by organizations such as the World Health Organization, which invited her to contribute to a landmark report on the role of arts in health promotion. This collaboration further solidified Bonnie's reputation as a leading authority in the field. As her research continued to flourish, Bonnie became an integral part of the ANU community. She developed and taught courses on music, health, and culture, inspiring a new generation of scholars to explore the intersections between these disciplines. Her mentorship and guidance helped shape the careers of numerous students, many of whom went on to become prominent researchers and practitioners in their own right. One of Bonnie's most notable contributions during her time at ANU was the establishment of the Music, Health, and Wellbeing Research Group. This interdisciplinary initiative brought together scholars from music, medicine, psychology, and anthropology to investigate the therapeutic potential of music in various healthcare settings.
content.source_2:
**LISBON, PORTUGAL - MARCH 15, 2044**

Renowned Ethnomusicologist and Health Educator Bonnie B. McConnell Joins NOVA School of Social Sciences and Humanities

In a move that is expected to further solidify NOVA University Lisbon's reputation as a hub for interdisciplinary research, Dr. Bonnie B. McConnell, a distinguished ethnomusicologist and health educator, has joined the faculty of the NOVA School of Social Sciences and Humanities. Dr. McConnell, who brings with her a wealth of experience in the fields of music, culture, and health, will be leading a new research initiative focused on the therapeutic applications of traditional music in modern healthcare settings. "We are thrilled to welcome Dr. McConnell to our team," said Dr. Maria José Magalhães, Dean of the NOVA School of Social Sciences and Humanities. "Her unique blend of expertise in ethnomusicology and health education will undoubtedly enrich our academic community and contribute to the development of innovative solutions for some of the world's most pressing health challenges." Dr. McConnell's research has taken her to various parts of the world, where she has studied the role of music in promoting physical and mental well-being in diverse cultural contexts. Her work has been published in numerous peer-reviewed journals and has been recognized with several prestigious awards. "I am excited to join the NOVA School of Social Sciences and Humanities and to contribute to the university's mission of fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and innovation," Dr. McConnell said in an interview. "I believe that music has the power to bring people together and to promote healing, and I look forward to exploring these ideas further with my new colleagues." Dr. McConnell's appointment is seen as a significant coup for NOVA University Lisbon, which has been actively seeking to expand its research capabilities in the areas of social sciences and humanities. "Dr. McConnell's expertise will not only enhance our research profile but also provide our students with opportunities to engage with cutting-edge ideas and approaches in the fields of music, culture, and health," said Dr. Magalhães.
